unnormalised: New Delhi - Well folks, looks like we're all officially time-traveling...sort of. Our esteemed (and possibly slightly confused) news anchor just announced that India's Chandrayaan-4 mission is slated for launch on 31/02/2028. Yes, you read that right, the 31st of February. Talk about being ahead of schedule! My chai nearly went flying across the studio.
normalised: New Delhi - Well folks, looks like we're all officially time-traveling... sort of. Our esteemed (and possibly slightly confused) news anchor just announced that India's Chandrayaan-four mission is slated for launch on thirty first february two thousand and twenty eight. Yes, you read that right, the thirty first of February. Talk about being ahead of schedule! My chai nearly went flying across the studio.

unnormalised: I mean, even the Earth's orbit isn't *that* wonky, right? Maybe ISRO knows something we don't, like they've invented a time machine disguised as a rocket. Imagine the possibilities! Avoiding that disastrous Monday meeting or reliving the glory days of 90s Bollywood.
normalised: I mean, even the Earth's orbit isn't that wonky, right? Maybe I-S-R-O knows something we don't, like they've invented a time machine disguised as a rocket. Imagine the possibilities! Avoiding that disastrous Monday meeting or reliving the glory days of nineties Bollywood.

unnormalised: Sources "close to the situation" (aka the intern who handles the coffee machine) suggest it was a "minor calendrical mishap." They assure us the launch date will be adjusted to something...well, real. They are aiming for 10/03/2028 now. A perfectly normal day.
normalised: Sources "close to the situation" (a-k-a the intern who handles the coffee machine) suggest it was a "minor calendrical mishap." They assure us the launch date will be adjusted to something... well, real. They are aiming for tenth march two thousand and twenty eight now. A perfectly normal day.

unnormalised: Adding to the confusion, the press release also mentioned the mission will be landing on Mars, scheduled for 13:13 hours IST. So, not only are we launching on a non-existent date, but we're also apparently bending the rules of time itself to land at a time that doesn't exist. One assumes the scientists have also cracked how to travel faster than the speed of light as well!
normalised: Adding to the confusion, the press release also mentioned the mission will be landing on Mars, scheduled for thirteen thirteen hours I-S-T. So, not only are we launching on a non-existent date, but we're also apparently bending the rules of time itself to land at a time that doesn't exist. One assumes the scientists have also cracked how to travel faster than the speed of light as well!

unnormalised: NASA are reportedly watching with popcorn in hand. "It is indeed an unorthodox approach," said one source within the organisation. "It could work, and we can learn from this".
normalised: N-A-S-A are reportedly watching with popcorn in hand. "It is indeed an unorthodox approach," said one source within the organization. "It could work, and we can learn from this".

unnormalised: Social media, naturally, has exploded. Memes are raining down faster than the Mumbai monsoon. Suggestions for alternative launch dates are flooding comment sections. Many people are also asking if 13:13 is auspicious, as this is a country of astrology lovers.
normalised: Social media, naturally, has exploded. Memes are raining down faster than the Mumbai monsoon. Suggestions for alternative launch dates are flooding comment sections. Many people are also asking if thirteen thirteen is auspicious, as this is a country of astrology lovers.

unnormalised: Meanwhile, back at the news desk, we're just trying to figure out how to prepone our weekend… since, you know, time is clearly relative now. Stay tuned for further updates on this chronologically challenged space adventure, and maybe consult your local astrologer before booking your trip to Mars. It should occur by 2030, one hopes. Or maybe never, given the uncertainty.
